body.p: Before installing the F5 BIG-IP driver in your Helion OpenStack deployment, make sure you fulfill all of the following requirements:

section.note: F5 BIG-IP currently supports only LBaaS Version 1. This is the version that was used to validate F5 BIG-IP integration with Helion OpenStack 2.0. The F5 LBaaS driver that was tested with Helion OpenStack 2.0 is planned to be officially supported in the next release of OpenStack.

Before continuing you must verify the LBaaS version you are using in your environment. If you have v2, to install the required version, v1, you can use the instructions in the Configuring Load Balance as a Service documentation.

section.title: Create Supported F5 Network Configuration
section.p: The goal of this networking setup is to create the F5 provider networks, subnets, and other networking elements that are necessary to run F5 with Helion OpenStack. To integrate F5 BIG-IP with Helion, there are certain network configurations that must be done.

ul.li: Management - Requires a new VLAN. This network is used for the BIG-IP management interface. This management network is different from the Helion management network, so make sure to give it a unique name. In this documentation we call it the "mgmt" network.

High Availability (HA) - Requires a new VLAN. This network is used for signaling between BIG-IP instances that are used for high availability purposes. This network is not required for standalone(non-HA) BIG-IP deployments.
Virtual Tunnel Endpoint (VTEP) network - Requires a free IP range from your GUEST_VXLAN. This is a data network.

section.note: To ensure there is no IP conflict, make sure you define the start and end IP range for GUEST_VXLAN. This setting can be found in the following file: ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/networks.conf

The new mgmt and HA VLAN's you create for F5 must be tagged. You can set the optional variable tagged-vlan to either “true” or “false”. If true, packets for the network carry the vlanid in the packet header; such packets are referred to as VLAN-tagged frames in IEEE 802.1Q. For information on how to set this option, read the Helion OpenStack 2.1 Example Configurations

dlentry.dt: Why do we need 3 Neutron provider networks?
dlentry.dd: A minimum of 2 logical interfaces, and a minimum of 3 VLANs is required. The first provider network would be a management VLAN that goes to the first interface. The second provider network would be external and the third one would be internal.

dlentry.dt: Do these Neutron provider networks need to have a router and be connected to an external network?
dlentry.dd: Only the external VLAN needs to have a router. The internal VLANs will share a subnet with the servers.

dlentry.dt: How do these provider networks talk to controller and compute nodes? Do they need any special routing?
dlentry.dd: You can add a fourth VXLAN network and have the F5 device talk directly to the compute nodes. No special routing is needed as long as the servers are connected to the same internal VLAN as BIG-IP.

dlentry.dt: On which tenant network should these provider networks be created?
dlentry.dd: During testing we used the admin tenant.

section.p: To integrate F5 Networks BIG-IP into your HPE Helion OpenStack deployment, you must create the following networks and verify they are working before you can install F5 drivers for BIG IP.
To configure your network to prepare for BIG-IP:

li.xref: Create a Virtual Tunnel Endpoint (VTEP) network

section.title: Create a Management Network
section.p: Integrating F5 BIG-IP with Helion OpenStack 2.0 requires that you create an additional management network. This network is used for the BIG-IP management interface. This management network is different from the Helion management network, so make sure to give it a unique name. In this documentation we call it the "mgmt" network.

The same VLAN that you create in these steps must be used to configure the F5 device for management network. The network you create in the following steps must be the same network VLAN that the F5 device management network is on.

ol.li: To create the network, replace the sample settings with the settings from your deployment in the following command and run:$ neutron net-create f5-mgmt --provider:physical_network physnet1 --provider:network_type vlan --provider:segmentation_id 102

To create a subnet, replace the sample settings with the settings from your deployment in the following command and run:$ neutron subnet-create f5-mgmt 10.1.36.0/24 --name f5-mgmt-subnet --gateway 10.1.36.1 --allocation-pool start=10.1.36.15,end=10.1.36.200
To create a router for the network, run: $ neutron router-create f5-mgmt-router
To create an interface between the router and the subnet, run:$ neutron router-interface-add f5-mgmt-router f5-mgmt-subnet
To set the router gateway to the external network, run:$ neutron router-gateway-set f5-mgmt-router ext-net

section.title: Create a High Availability Network
section.p: Integrating F5 BIG-IP with Helion OpenStack requires that you create a high availability (HA) network. You must create this network using a VLAN that is not in use anywhere else.
To create a high availability network:

ol.li: To create the network, use the settings for your deployment in the following command and run:$ neutron net-create F5-HA --provider:physical_network physnet1 --provider:network_type vlan --provider:segmentation_id 103
To create a subnet, use the settings for your deployment in the following command and run:$ neutron subnet-create F5-HA 10.1.37.0/24 --name F5-HA-subnet --gateway 10.1.37.1
To create a router for the network, run:$ neutron router-create F5-HA-router
To create an interface between the router and the subnet, run:$ eutron router-interface-add F5-HA-router F5-HA-subnet
To set the router gateway to the external network, run:$ neutron router-gateway-set F5-HA-router ext-net

section.title: Create a Virtual Tunnel Endpoint (VTEP) Network
section.p: Integrating F5 BIG-IP with Helion OpenStack 2.0 requires that you create a virtual tunnel endpoint (VTEP) network. You must create this network using a free IP range from your GUEST_VXLAN VLAN.

ol.li: To create the network, use the settings for your deployment in the following command and run:$ neutron net-create f5-vtep --provider:physical_network physnet1 --provider:network_type vlan --provider:segmentation_id 106

To create a subnet, use the settings for your deployment in the following command and run:$ neutron subnet-create f5-vtep 10.1.40.0/24 --name f5-vtep-subnet --gateway 10.1.40.1 --allocation-pool start=10.1.40.200,end=10.1.40.254
To create a router for the network, run:$ neutron router-create F5-vtep-router
To create an interface between the router and the subnet, run:$ neutron router-interface-add F5-vtep-router F5-vtep-subnet
To set the router gateway to the external network, run:$ neutron router-gateway-set F5-vtep-router ext-net

section.title: Verify Your Network Connectivity
section.p: After creating the management, high availability (HA), and virtual tunnel endpoint (VTEP) networks, you should verify connectivity before installing the F5 BIG-IP driver. Ping the IP of the VM from compute nodes ONLY as the pool members will be residing on compute nodes. When the PING test passes on the compute nodes, you can install the F5 LBaaS driver.

ol.li: Launch a virtual machine (VM) on your mgmt (management) network.
To ping an IP address, from the compute node, run:$ ping <ipaddress_of_virtual_machine>
Repeat these steps for other F5 networks.
Repeat these steps for other HA networks.
Repeat these steps for other VTEP networks.
